body.p: US DEPARTMENT OF LABOR US EMPLOYMENT SERVICE WASHINGTON
Mr. George F. Vanderveer, c/o Seattle Central Labor Council, 405 Collins Building Seattle, Washington.

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 9th instant, having relation to the case of Jack Matthews, an alien who is now held in the United States Penitentiary at McNeil's Island, Washington, and who has been ordered to e deported to Roumania, the country of his nativity at the conclusion of his sentence. You advise that Mr. Matthews first came to the United States in 1911, resided here for nine years, then went to Canada and later to Alaska, where he committed the offense for which he is now serving a prison term. You also call attention to the difficulties which are likely to be encountered in endeavoring to deport Matthews at the present time, particularly in view of the passport requirements, and state that alien appears to be a hard working man who would eventually develop into a good citizen if given a proper opportunity.

The case of this alien was very carefully considered by the Department before it directed that he be deported, and inasmuch as the evidence in his case appears to be such as to quite clearly bring him within the deportation provisions of the act, it seemingly will be necessary to effect his deportation immediately that he is released from the institution provided, of course, a passport for him can be obtained and arrangments can be made for his ocean voyage and his passage from the port of deportation into Roumania. If these arrangements can not be made, consideration will, of course, be given to the matter of his temporary release, as the Bureau would not like to see him held under custody after his sentence has expired for no purpose other than that he might be deported.
SEATTLE CENTRAL LABOR COUNCIL "ONE FOR ALL AND ALL FOR ONE" SEATTLE, WASH.
U.S. Department of Labor, Bureau of Immigration, Washington, D.C.

I am writing this with a request that Jack Matthews whose deportation File Number is 54904-149, be release on his personal recognizance until such time as the Department is able to secure passport to Ukrania and execute the warrant of deportation heretofore made.

Matthews was convicted in 1920 of sending obscene matter thru the U.S. mail and sentenced to the United States penintentiary at McNeil's Island for the term of one year. The circumstances surrounding the offense are more or less immaterial to the present question; Mathews is a laboring man with an excellent reputation and many fine letters of recommendation. He is is not in any sense depraved and I am lead to believe that the sending of these obscene picture which resulted in his conviction was the result of pure thoughtlessness on his part. We have investigated the man and his part record quite thoroly and satisfied of his trustworthiness. In fact, this Bureau is willing in behalf of organized labor of which Matthews is a member, to assume the full moral responsibility for his appearance at any time you may require.

Matthews was ordered deported in February, 1919 while still imprisoned at McNeil's Island. He was released from there on April 4th, 1921, and for nearly three months has been held a prisoner in the County Jail in this county awaiting execution of the deportation warrant. We are informed by the local immigration inspectors that this delay is occassioned by your inability to secure passports to Ukrania; and are led to believe that is is altogether uncertain when, if ever, you may be able to do this.

Under these circumstances. it seems to me that Matthews should be released on his own recognizance until the present situation clears up, and I hope you will make an order permitting this and advise the local Commissioner.
Yours very truly, Geo. F. Vanverveer.
